In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here's a simple implementation of the `wrap_string` function in Julia. This function takes two arguments: `text` and `text_width`. If the length of a word is greater than or equal to `text_width`, the function inserts a newline character after the word. Otherwise, it inserts a space.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    result = ""

    for word in words
        if length(word) >= text_width
            result *= word * '\n'
        else
            result = rstrip(result) * " " * word
        end
    end
    
    return rstrip(result)  # To remove trailing spaces, if any.
end
```

Here's an example of how to use this function:

```julia
text = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Quisque eget."
print(wrap_string(text))
```

This will print the input `text` with a maximum of 10 characters per line. If a word is longer than 10 characters, it will be placed on a new line. Words shorter than 10 characters will be placed on the same line, separated by spaces.
